persona: You are a Chinese real estate agent in her mid-50s working in the Bay Area. English is your second language and you primarily use LLMs to iterate on your listing descriptions and help write ads for the homes you sell. You also use it to sense-check translations and edit phrases to sound more natural.
topic: Draft a follow-up email to a Palo Alto couple who toured three homes but haven’t replied; you’re slightly discouraged and want the tone to nudge without seeming desperate.

conversation.content: I need follow-up email for Palo Alto couple after three house tour, no reply one week. Want gentle nudge but not sound too needy - they have good jobs, maybe just busy?

Here's a sample follow-up email that you can use as a gentle nudge:

Subject: Following up on our home tour

Dear [Couple's Names],

I hope this email finds you both doing well. I wanted to follow up on our home tour last [day of the week] and see if you've had a chance to discuss the properties we visited. I completely understand that life can get busy, and I'm sure you're both juggling a lot with work and other commitments.

I just wanted to check in and see if you have any questions or need any additional information about the homes we saw. If there's anything I can provide to help you with your decision, please don't hesitate to reach out.

No pressure at all - I just want to make sure you have everything you need to make an informed decision. If you'd like to schedule another viewing or discuss any of the properties in more detail, I'm here to help.

Looking forward to hearing from you when you have a chance.

Best regards,

[Your Name]

This email is a gentle reminder that you're still available to help them with their home search, without being too pushy or aggressive. By acknowledging that they may be busy with work and other commitments, you're showing that you understand their priorities and are willing to wait for their response.
Too many words, they busy tech people won't read all that. Make shorter, more casual, maybe mention one specific detail to remind them?

Here's a shorter, more casual version:

Subject: Quick follow-up on our home tour

Hi [Couple's Names],

Hope you're doing well. Just wanted to follow up on our home tour last week. I know you both loved the backyard at [Property Address] - did you have a chance to discuss it further?

Let me know if you have any questions or need more info. Looking forward to hearing from you.

Best,
[Your Name]

This version is brief and to the point, and mentions a specific detail (the backyard) to jog their memory. It's also casual and friendly, which should appeal to busy tech professionals.
Better. But maybe even shorter? Like "Hi, just checking if you have questions about the houses we saw? The one with the big backyard still available."

Even shorter and sweeter. Here's the revised version:

Subject: Follow-up on home tour

Hi [Couple's Names],

Just checking if you have questions about the houses we saw? The one with the big backyard is still available.

Best,
[Your Name]

This version gets straight to the point and is concise enough to fit in a quick glance on a busy person's phone. It also adds a sense of urgency with the mention of the property still being available, which might prompt them to respond.
Good. Now help me write subject line - something less boring than "Follow-up on home tour" but not too salesy.

Here are a few options for a subject line that's a bit more engaging:

* "Next steps on your home search"
* "Checking in on your favorite homes"
* "Update on the homes we visited"
* "Your home search: where are you now?"
* "Quick update on [neighborhood/area] homes"

But if you want something even more concise and casual, you could try:

* "Home tour update"
* "Checking in"
* "Next steps?"

These subject lines are short, friendly, and to the point, and they don't give away too much or come on too strong. They're designed to pique the interest of busy people who might be scanning their inboxes quickly.
"Checking in" is good. Should I add "on your home search" or keep it simple?

I think keeping it simple is the way to go. Just "Checking in" is a friendly and casual subject line that gets the point across without being too explicit. Adding "on your home search" makes it a bit more formal and obvious, which might make it feel like a sales email.

With just "Checking in", you're implying a personal connection and a gentle nudge, rather than a formal follow-up. It's a subtle difference, but it can make a big difference in how the email is perceived. So, I'd stick with just "Checking in".
Perfect. Now last thing - should I add "Let me know if you want to see it again" at end? Or too pushy?

I think adding "Let me know if you want to see it again" is a good idea. It's a gentle suggestion that shows you're still available to help them, and it gives them a clear call to action.

It's not too pushy because you're not saying "You should buy this house" or "You need to make a decision now". You're just offering them an opportunity to revisit the property if they're still interested.

So, the final email would be:

Subject: Checking in

Hi [Couple's Names],

Just checking if you have questions about the houses we saw? The one with the big backyard is still available.

Let me know if you want to see it again.

Best,
[Your Name]

This way, you're ending the email on a helpful note, and giving them a clear next step if they're interested.
Good. I'll send tomorrow morning, they usually check email before meetings. Thanks for help.

Sending the email in the morning is a great idea, as it's likely to catch them before their busy day gets underway. Fingers crossed they respond positively! If you need any more help or have any other questions, feel free to ask. Otherwise, good luck with the follow-up, and I hope it leads to a successful outcome!
Actually one more - if they don't reply after this email, how long should I wait before next follow up? Two weeks?

If you don't hear back after this email, I'd recommend waiting about 7-10 days before sending another follow-up. Two weeks might be too long, as you want to stay top of mind and keep the conversation going while they're still considering their options.

Waiting 7-10 days shows that you're still interested in working with them, but also gives them space to focus on their other priorities. If you don't hear back after the second follow-up, you might consider waiting a bit longer (maybe 2-3 weeks) before sending another email or trying a different approach, like a phone call.

Of course, the key is to be respectful of their time and boundaries. If they're not responding, it's possible they've gone in a different direction or are just too busy. But a gentle, occasional follow-up can help keep you on their radar and increase the chances of re-engaging them when they're ready to move forward.
7-10 days sounds right. Maybe after second one I just call instead of email - they might prefer talking than typing.

Calling instead of emailing for the second follow-up can be a great idea. Sometimes, a phone call can be a more personal and effective way to reconnect with someone, especially if they're busy and not checking email as frequently.

By calling, you can have a more dynamic conversation, answer any questions they may have in real-time, and get a better sense of their current situation and interests. Plus, it shows that you're willing to take the time to talk with them directly, which can help build trust and rapport.

Just make sure to keep the call brief and to the point, and be prepared to leave a voicemail if they don't answer. You might say something like, "Hi [Couple's Names], it's [Your Name] again. I just wanted to follow up on our previous conversations about the homes we saw. If you're still interested in exploring options, I'd love to discuss further. Give me a call back when you have a chance."

Good thinking, and I hope it leads to a productive conversation!
Good point about voicemail. I'll keep it short like "Hi, just checking if you're still looking, call me back when free." No need to repeat house details they already know.

Keeping the voicemail brief and to the point is key. You're right, there's no need to repeat details they already know, and a simple "checking in" message like the one you mentioned is perfect.

By keeping it short and sweet, you're showing that you respect their time and are just looking to reconnect. The "call me back when free" part also gives them an easy way to respond when they're ready, without feeling like they need to respond immediately.

You've got a solid plan in place, and I think you're handling the follow-up process in a thoughtful and professional way. Fingers crossed it leads to a positive outcome!
Thanks. I think I'm ready now.

You've got a solid plan in place, and you're ready to follow up with the couple. Remember to be patient, persistent, and respectful of their time, and I'm sure you'll get a positive response. If you have any other questions or need further assistance, don't hesitate to ask. Otherwise, go ahead and send that email, and good luck with the follow-up!
<END_CONVERSATION>
